pros: I can't recommend NCHA highly enough. For anybody who wants to put their energy towards solving the social issues that really count today, like the housing crisis or the social care crisis, this is your place. I've felt supported to develop in a friendly and effective environment full of people who really care. Decent pension scheme, really good healthcare+wellbeing support, loads of training and development opportunities. Couldn't be happier overall.
cons: Not many. The basic pay isn't amazing, but in general i'd say that's made up for by the other benefits, and by feeling part of something that matters.

pros: Good Place to work and fantastic benefits
cons: Sometimes there could be lack of direction from leaders

Shifts run on very little staff. 
Don’t get paid enough for the work load you have to deal with. 
Went in as support worker for autism and learning disabilities but it was more like an home for the elderly with pretty much all service users being of an older age and needing lots and lots and lots of personal care! 
Staff that have been there for years seem very pessimistic about new staff and the shadow shifts when you 1st start are not good.

job_title: Marketing Communications Officer in Nottingham, England
pros: Good pay in comparison to similar roles, flexible working, excellent colleague benefits, opportunities to go to social events.
cons: Due to the spread of the business across the East Midlands, colleagues can find it difficult to meet, but that is being worked on at the moment.

pros:
Look after you
Feel part of a family
Good training

job_title: Property Marketing Officer in Nottingham, England
pros:
Flexible working policy
Great benefits including extra holiday, pension contribution, healthcare package
Training and development
Management genuinely care about their customers and staff
cons: Nothing at the moment, very happy

review_title: Diverse Role where you will learn on the job
job_title: Response and Support Officer in Nottingham, England
cons: Long and irregular shift patterns which make it hard to find a work life balance

pros: Great people, good benefits and training.
cons: pay in some roles could be better

job_title: Care Assistant/Project Worker in Nottingham, England
pros: I have been privileged to work for approximately four years flexibly within the NCHA HWCS PST in Mansfield, Nottingham and later on in Ripley providing a person-centred approach to both Domiciliary Care in the Community and Enhanced Supported Living to service users and other individuals enabling them to maintain their independence and mobility while preserving their dignity and well-being. I have also been privileged to work with some very hardworking, caring and helpful colleagues and members of staff who are always ready to go the extra mile for the service user .  Excellent training is given and consistently updated and one can attend training relevant to one's duties and receive the certificate afterwards.
cons: Split shifts can be very tiring and hard-going and where no split-shifts, full day-time hours sometimes have no adequate break-time for refreshments or even going to the loo when out and about. Impossible rotas when there is never enough travelling time between distance from one visit to the other which can aggravate an already irate service user for arriving late.

job_title: SMaRT Response Team in Nottingham, England
pros:
Fantastic and rewarding job
Varied and intense shifts
Fantastic Managers 
Great Training and skills gained 
Nice salary 
exceedingly  good cake making 
One staff member anger to taxi drivers 😂
cons:
They encorage a backstabbing culture
Idle  staff get rewarded and praised
Bullying & cliques by above before service users. They will set you up to make you look bad ie sending you to wrong postcode for a laugh. 
Very stressful job emergency service staff should only apply 
Team Leaders clashed too much 
Too much new work taken on without hiring staff. Your job will change when you have had a day off literally!! 
Macdonalds left in SMaRT cars
This job is GUARANTEED to make you FAT! Look at the staff pictures over time! 
Mentor was patronising. Learned more in 2 mins from a female staff member overlooked to train. 
Rota confusion someone always misses a shift at some point.

pros: i have worked for Nottingham Community Housing Association for almost 5 years and will be sad to leave next month, within the 5 years i have had three different job titles, care assistant, support worker(both in the same registered care home) and customer adviser due to the home getting shut and having to be redeployed. NCHA were my first proper employer and i couldn't have been happier with them. the pay is great, the annual leave is wonderful and they are genuinely a great company!
cons: i wouldn't say i have any negative thoughts on the company, my experience has been good. I would say though from working in the HWCS(housing with care and support) side it can be a bit short staffed so if someone doesn't take you off your shift it can be a pain to cover!

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Nottingham, England
pros: From day one I have been accepted within the team straight away. The atmosphere at work is very positive and I would never be afraid of going to someone for assistance.  I have been given many opportunities already in my short employment with NCHA which helps to develop my skills and keeps me interested in the role as there is always something new to learn/develop. It is very reassuring to see a company with so many long time employees as usually the turn around is very short for recruitment in companies.
cons: Too many people bring in cakes and donuts and it isn't so good for the dieting!

pros: Trust to get on with the job in hand, and little need to check in with line manager. Able to influence some structures and ways things are done.
cons: Far too bureaucratic and departments not willing to work flexibly with each other. Far too many changes occurring with posts appearing to either be created for individuals or recruitment not being transparent and going to people whose face fits.

pros: Great staff and manager. Plus the work is worth while when you feel you have helped people out. Training is helpful you can choose what courses to do. Also you can gain certificates for the training.
cons: the premises are okay but it is dark in the office plus there is one toilet for the three businesses.

pros: Enjoyed working here, great service users, face to face training all free, pay was better than some places
cons: I was bank and often couldn’t get shifts but couldn’t get a contract as no car.

job_title: Mental Health Support Worker in Nottingham, England
pros: Flexible working,local projects,wide variety of care positions,person centred approach to care provided
cons: Shift work,sometimes lack of training when first employed

pros: Customer focused, reputable, respectable and fair
